p: Human settlements have increased in global proportion, especially during the last century [ 1]. Urban settlements range from villages with fuzzy boundaries in rural areas to large cities with dense human populations. Over time, villages growing into towns and towns growing into cities result in rapid infrastructural densification [ 2, 3]. While large cities are becoming more prevalent, classification boundaries between types of settlements are often unclear [ 4]. Yet, urban settlements are generally hardscapes overlying greenscapes [ 5]. Gradients of urbanization have complex consequences for the global natural environment [ 6, 7]. These impacts broadly include habitat loss, pollution, alien vegetation encroachment, and changes in microclimates, and their effects often extend far beyond settlement centers [ 8, 9, 10].
